campaign.story:
Thrilling Adventure Yarns!
The pulp magazines were a gateway to other worlds and times. It was where some of the greatest writers of the 20th Century got their start and some of the most iconic characters made their debut, from Edgar Rice Burroughs' Tarzan and John Carter to Maxwell Grant's The Shadow to Robert E. Howard's Conan the Barbarian. 
Without the pulps, comic books may never have introduced the super-hero...and then where would we be today?
The pulp magazine era was bristling with brawny men and statuesque women globetrotting, and getting into and out of danger. Their exploits quickened the pulses of their readers, young and old alike. They gave rise to some of the most enduring heroes known the world 'round.
To honor and celebrate a bygone era, I have partnered with most of my Crazy 8 Press team. If you've loved Aaron Rosenberg's work on ReDeus or From this is Hell or Paul Kupperberg's super-hero comics and adventure stories or the intergalactic adventures from Mary Fan or the noirish stylings of Russ Colchamiro, then you know what you're in for. Aaron, Paul, Mary, the late Glenn Hauman, and Michael Jan Friedman are all signed on for the project. 
Additionally, I have assembled a stellar line-up of other writers – Derek Tyler Attico, Jim & Becky Beard, Paige Daniels, Kathleen O'Shea David, Robert T. Jeschonek, Amy Lewanski, Karissa Laurel, and Jenifer Purcell Rosenberg – to produce new thrills and chills, spanning the traditional pulp realms of mystery, sword and sorcery, horror, science fiction, romance, and high adventure, in a volume appropriately titled...Thrilling Adventure Yarns!
Meet Professor Ironheart! The Blue Mask! The Green Lady! Cannon Belle! And many more brand-new heroes that would have made pulp-era creators proud.
An Historic Coup!
We have also secured the rights to a true relic of the glory days of the pulps: A previously unpublished World War I aviator tale by none other than Lester Dent, the creator of Doc Savage! This is a milestone in the history of the pulp magazines, available only to the backers of this campaign. 
We're really excited about Thrilling Adventure Yarns -- in part, at least, because of this great cover by the inestimable British artist Alex Ronald. Feast your eyes on this image and you can see for yourself that the days of yore will be treated with deep affection.
Our goal!
This isn't the kind of publishing project in which the publisher takes the lion's share of the profits and doles out the scraps to those who've done all the work. All funds that remain after the expenses of acquiring the Lester Dent story, commissioning the cover, designing the book, funding a print run, and sending out rewards to our backers will be divvied up by our editor and our writers in equal amounts. If we reach our goal of at least $4,500, we'll be able to accomplish all that.
But it's our hope to earn enough to add some other authors as well, and maybe, just maybe, to reach a stretch goal that will enable us to add interior illustrations.
It all comes down to you.
A la carte!
This handy-dandy a la carte menu enables you to customize your reward package--to receive all the things you want and none of the things you don't. Just take any existing package of $25 and up and add to it the dollar amount associated with any item or items on the following list. Then send us a message letting us know what additional reward or rewards you've qualified for. (International backers, there will be some additional postage; if you're interested in an add-on, shoot us a message and we'll figure it out.)
Get listed as a patron on the acknowledgments page                                     10. 
Receive a one-time mention as a character, street, company, etc.             35.
Crazy 8 e-book package #1                                                                                   20. 
Crazy 8 e-book package #2                                                                                   20.
Crazy 8 e-book package #3                                                                                   20.
Package #1 includes Six Scarlet Scorpions (a Pat Savage novel) by Will Murray; No Small Bills by Aaron Rosenberg; In My Shorts (a short story collection) by Paul Kupperberg; Pulling Up Stakes by Peter David; ReDeus: Divine Tales, and The Fire Dragon by Mary Fan.
Package #2 includes The Camelot Papers by Peter David; Finders Keepers by Russ Colchamiro; Flynn Nightsider and the Edge of Evil by Mary Fan; a collection of five short stories by Keith R.A. DeCandido; For This Is Hell by Aaron Rosenberg and Steve Saville, and Fight The Gods by Michael Jan Friedman.
Package #3 is a Crazy 8 Press Anthology pack that includes the entire Latchkeys series; ReDeus: Divine Lands; Love, Mayhem, and Murder; They Keep Killing Glenn, and Tales of the Crimson Keep.
For $20 more, you can upgrade your trade paperback to a hardcover edition (after the option is unlocked, of course). 
Stretch Goals!
$5,000 will allow me to include stories from three long-time reader favorites: Keith R.A. DeCandido, Will Murray and Peter David.
In many ways, Will has been almost single-handedly keeping the pulps alive with his articles and short stories throughout the years. He's also been writing authorized novels featuring Doc Savage, Tarzan, and others. He knows his way around a good yarn.
Keith is the award-winning author of more than fifty books, including some of the best Star Trek novels around. And his Dragon Precinct books have a cult following all their own.
Peter is the famed Writer of Stuff whose pulp-inspired works include several Zorro stories. But really, we know and love him for his runs on The Incredible Hulk, Young Justice, and Star Trek. His original works range from science fiction to satirical vampire tales.
New! At $6,000, we unlock "the hardcover option," allowing any backer whose reward includes a paperback copy on to upgrade to a handsome hardback version of Thrilling Adventure Yarns (see A La Carte menu above).
New! At $6500 we will upgrade those receiving one signature to three signatures from our illustrious cadre of authors.
$7000 will allow me to hire a cadre of talented artists to render a black and white illustration for each and every story in the collection. 
At $8,000 we can send everyone a digital art set of images, suitable for your digital wallpaper. 
New! At $9000, we will send every backer a digital copy of Peter David's Sir Apropos of Nothing, his critically acclaimed humorous fantasy novel. It's the first in a series and the long-out-of-print second and third volumes will finally be available once more in the summer so now's a great time to get introduced to the series.
New! At $10,000 we will up our guarantee of three autographs per print edition to five autographs.
We'll be announcing other stretch goals as our campaign develops. We don't want to give away all our secrets!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The manuscript is nearly complete already, with 90% of the stories in and more than half of them already edited. The cover, as you can see, is finished except for the logo and trade dress. And as someone who's edited and published books for DC Comics and Marvel, this is hardly my first go-around as a talent wrangler.

Of course, there are always unforeseen obstacles. But barring something horrific, we'll deliver what we've promised well within the time parameters in which we've promised it.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The Story
How does humanity fare in a world where death isn’t the end? Vancouver, British Columbia found out after a breakout of White Sun, a virus capable of bringing back the dead in a viciously primal state. Panic turned into destruction as corpses marched through the streets, tearing at the flesh of anyone in their wake. 
Hope was fleeting. 
Global superpowers came together and formed the International Bio-disaster Response Agency (IBRA). Cleaner Squads were dispatched into the unfolding crisis. Their mission: extract the living and clear out any dead that stands in their way.
Bruce Deacon, fireteam leader of CS-42, was among the first wave to arrive. Entering the besieged city only to discover…
In Vancouver, when it rains it pours.  
What is Vancity Outbreak?
Vancity Outbreak is a graphic novel about a deadly virus that turns victims into ravenous undead cannibals. Bruce Deacon, the squad leader of a bio-disaster response team, is sent to rescue the survivors trapped within the city. He meets a student nurse named Jane Riley and together they work to escape the quarantine zone. Only to discover that they bit off more than they could chew.
Whiplash Comics uses real actors and real locations. We tell stories through the medium of a camera and create stunning visuals through composting the photographs. The result is a truly unique style that pushes the boundaries of storytelling. 
Our cast includes real models, actors, makeup artist, musicians, and other creatives. Together, with very small budget, we put together TWO action-packed issues. Reid Lucier tailored each photo using graphic compositing to add the effects while working with Cale Boudreau to input the story. 
We've had a booth at Vancouver’s zombie walk, comic conventions and met with successful creators to learn everything we can. It paid off and we want to continue going forward! With your help we can pay for the printing costs, shipping fees, and begin working on future comics!

Samples of Issue 1 - Bullet or a Bite

Samples of Issue 1 - Bullet or a Bite

Reward Tiers
Tier 1 - Bite
Tier 2 - Infection
Tier 3 - Viral Spread
Tier 4 - Outbreak

Tier 6 - Apocalypse
Tier 7 - Annihilation
Our Vision
Whiplash Comics brings graphic novels to life through photography. With a successful Kickstarter, we can bring both issues of Vancity Outbreak to market, tainted with our blood, sweat and tears.
And we don't plan on stopping there! 
We have more stories in the works including: issue #3 of Vancity Outbreak, a spy comic, a VR short movie based on Vancity Outbreak, and even branching off into illustrated comics.
With enough support we can deliver more jaw-dropping visual storytelling. We made Vancity Outbreak with a budget of $200, having a group of creatives from all walks of life come together through nothing but passion. 
Our goal moving forward, however, is to offer compensation to the actors, extras, make-up artists, and everyone else that contributes. This is an important step if we want to maintain our cast for continuity sake. The photoshoots last anywhere from 10-12 hours and often require re-shoots. Tons of work pours into each comic which requires intricate planning to put together. 
WHO ARE WE?
Reid
Cale
What's the backstory? How did Vancity Outbreak come about?
Reid Lucier had the idea for Vancity Outbreak after finishing a zombie themed photoshoot with our resident Bruce (Roberto Lanzas) and Jane (Yu Sarah Matsushita). After editing the first photo, he noticed how cinematic the shots were and found the inspiration to make a comic. Reid created a short PDF comic book with the photos he had.  A year later Reid decided he wanted to continue Vancity Outbreak and really do it right with a full graphic novel in mind.  After bringing up the idea to the original cast and receiving a lot of enthusiasm from them to do more, Reid sat down to write a full graphic novel.  It took all about 10 mins to realize writing was not his speciality.
That’s when he met Cale Boudreau, a creative writer and zombie fanatic, online. Together, with couple cold ones and some poutine they created the vision for the comic.  They began casting actors, makeup artist, and looking for props and locations to shoot.  Shedding their blood, sweat, and tears to make it happen. 
Two full issues were shot, and Reid went to work on editing, and layout, special effects etc. Now finally we are thrilled to get these issues into your hands!
Why back us?
Because we know where you live, and the next time you open your front door we'll have our undead associate waiting for you...
Our associate :)
 Just kidding...maybe? 

Printing
Size: 6.6 by 10.25 inches
Cover:  10pt paper stock, Matte anti-scratch, green foil stamping
Inside paper stock:  85lbs matte
Binding: Perfect Softcover
We shopped around and did our research.  We walked a few indie comic events and 8/10 books we picked up, flipped through and impressed us were from Print Ninja.  We contacted Print Ninja and they sent us a few samples. The one style of graphic novel sent over was perfect.  The look, the feel, the fantastic quality...we knew we had to have it. Pricier than other places we contacted, but will be well worth it. We want top quality for us and most of all, our fans!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
With any creation process there are challenges. With a photographic comic these problems become more complex.

Here's the good news: All the work is done and the first two comics are 100% complete! We simply need help to fund our first printing run and to bring forth all the great rewards with it. 

We have a TON of interest from actors wanting to join future projects. If our stretch goal is met, we can begin creating issue #3 and offer an incentive to the cast to devote more hard work and time.

When using real people, conflicting schedules can occur such as people dropping out of the project and doing reshoots. These are working professionals in the industry so their schedules are often hard to align. 

Our contingency here is find a day that works for everyone. We can also break up shoots into two smaller days. In the event of a character dropping out, we can either handle this in two ways: find a suitable replacement or go with the fun option…give them a glorious death!

Beyond any logistical problems with delivering comics, we have to deliver the rewards which are ready to go. All we need to do is ship them!

SUNDAY 9TH OF DECEMBER - EAST GRINSTEAD CINEMA (ATRIUM) 
6:30 PM - DOORS - 7:00 PM - FILM STARTS 7:15 PM
update: CERTIFICATE: 12A 
"The Bastard Sword" is an independent next-to-no budget fantasy adventure film. In the ancient forest of Soza, a fighter, a thief and a hermit go searching for a magical sword that can control minds!
It was shot in the woods by the Yoghurt Rooms in East Grinstead with some scenes in Ashdown Forest.
We are hosting a MOVIE PREMIERE in the East Grinstead Cinema on Sunday the 9th of December. In order to do this screening, and hopefully more in the future, we need a BBFC certificate, and they're very expensive!
With your support, we hope to screen this film, not only for this story, but on behalf of all micro-budget film makers. We want to bring big independent features into the cinema, where they should be!
The film stars Xander Phillips as Tias, Seth Easterbrook as Ulysses, and Martyn Eade as Mars. It's a more classic style fantasy, with a fully original classical score, which I have written myself.
We recommend arriving at the event at 6:30 PM
The doors will open at 7:00 PM and there will be one intermission in the middle of the film. The cast and crew will be there, handing out awards to pledgers, answering questions, and trying our best to hide our nerves (me in particular!)
Your pledge will help us to cover the costs of this release. Not the film cost itself. We paid for that for the love of making film. The budget was probably around £2000 in total, mainly due to old style clothing and you guessed it - swords! This funding will help mostly with the certificate, the theatre rental, and if we overshoot our goal, it will begin to help cover costs of printing, ink, paper, cases, posters and rewards.
Above all, your pledge will - quite honestly - give us a little more hope in this field of art. To make something that people give a chance, to give their time and money to experience something new, whether good or bad, gives us the ability to learn from the experience, and a little more confidence in putting the time and money into future films.
UPDATE ON THE RATING: It is now a 12A, confirmed!
If your kids like classic fantasy adventure, bring them! :D
This is a "fantasy epic" so it's not short. It has been cut down, so it's faster-paced, but after debating for a long time, I could not bring myself to divide this film into two halves. Although it was almost possible, it would have spoiled the structure of the script, and the way it was intended to be. But as promised, a 15-minute intermission, and some possible surprises during :) Like the way cinema used to be!
Please pass this link to anyone who you think it might appeal to. We're always looking to build relationships with backers who may also be trying to get into the film-making game. That's the whole idea!
Thank you for your time in looking at our film, and I look forward to meeting you and posting all those rewards. It's going to be a blast!
PS: Please make sure you put your FULL NAME on the pledge! Thank you! :)

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As with my previous kick-starter campaign, I don't like to take big risks. I ask for help at the last minute, well after I've done everything I can. (Although one day, I hope to try new methods!) Therefore there are practically no risks for backers.

The film has already been written, shot, edited and scored. We are in the absolute final stages of audio mixing, which will probably be done by the time this kick-starter is launched. I will then test it with Chris on the projector, make any adjustments, test again (I usually aim for first or second test to be the final one), then it's done. If I die, the show goes on. If the cinema gets fried by a dragon, then we might have a problem.

Since the campaign ends the day before the premiere, the film is scheduled to be tested within a week from now. The only risks are technical ones, computers deciding to fight me, which I am pretty used to by now! If some horrific freak technical problem happens and the Premiere can't go on, then I would know well before the kick-starter would end, and would not allow it to take the money from its backers in the first place. I have already started production on the rewards, which are relatively easy to complete at this stage from previous experience.
VHS is a bit of a tricky one, but we reckon we've solved it doing some tests.
When the film is on that projector, tested and given the nod, it stays there. It sleeps until the day our supporters arrive, and then, IT'S TIME FOR THE SWORD!!

campaign.story:
First, please watch the video and read the story that will follow this.  My name is A. M. Paulson.  I am a dyslexic writer with a few stories published and am writing a comic book series through Oneshi Press.  I had lots of issues in school with spelling and reading with the letter 'c' being a true enemy of mine for my early grade school years.  Later in life I learned a rule to spell with the letter 'c'.  The letter 'c' sounds like a 'k' before a, o, and u as in cat, cot, and cut.  The letter 'c' sounds like an 's' before e, i, and y as in cent, city, and cyst.  Now I am inspired to write a picture book to teach this rule to help other kids like myself.  I sent it to many publishers, but they had no idea what to do with it and rejected it on the grounds they didn't know who would buy it.  I know this story can help many kids, so I got together with a friend, and we planing to put it on Amazon Kindle.  We need $100 for art supplies  and to pay the artist.  We have other goals as well.  
Those goals are...
$200 for an audio book
$300 for a paperback printed edition
$500 for a hardback printed edition
$1000 for an animated short of the story
I am not one to ask you to give money without seeing the manuscript.  So, the rest of this post is the story 'Mary and the Letter C.'  I hope you enjoy it ;)
Mary and the Letter C
By: A. M. Paulson
Mary was very sad. She had failed her spelling test, and her parents said it was because she did not try hard enough to learn to spell the words.
“How can you spell the word ‘cat’ k-a-t?” her dad had asked.
“The word ‘city’ begins with a ‘c’ not a ‘s’,” her mother had said. “Everyone knows that.”
Mary had tried to tell her parents she spelled the words the way they sounded just like her teacher told her to do, but they wouldn’t listen. Instead they sent her to her room without any dinner.
As she sat on her bed, Mary decided the only reason she failed the test was because of the letter “c.” She wondered why the letter “c” sounded like the letter “s” when you sang the alphabet song, but when used in words, it sometimes sounded like a “k,” for example in “cat.” For hours, she thought and thought. 
Mary thought about how the letter “c” doesn’t really have a sound of its own.
Mary thought about how the letter “c” steals spelling jobs from “s’s” and “k’s.”
Mary thought about how much better the world would be without the letter “c.”
Mary thought about hammering out the letter “c” into the letter “I” or squeezing it into the letter “o,” or bending it into the letter “v.” 
Until at last, she fell asleep. 
In middle of the night, a sound woke Mary up. Jumping up and down on her bed was a fairy. The fairy had the wings of a honeybee and a dress made of letters.
“Hello,” said the fairy. “I’m Spella, the fairy of spelling and grammar. I’m here to teach you about the letter ‘c’.”
Mary closed her eyes to go back to sleep. 
“I don’t want to learn about the letter ‘c’.” Mary said. “Go away, so I can go back to sleep.”
Spella flew over to Mary and whispered in her ear, “Learning about ‘c’ will help you pass your next spelling test.”
Mary opened one eye. “It will?”
Spella nodded. “I promise.”
Mary sat up.
Spella flew to the middle of the room and clapped her hands, and the letters “c,” “s,” and “k” appeared. 
“You are right about the letter ‘c’ being troublesome,” Spella said. “Lots of children your age have trouble knowing which of these three letters to use at the beginning of a word.”
“But my parents said no one had trouble with it,” Mary said, remembering what her mom and dad had said before they sent her to her room.
Spella shrugged. “Some people have no problem with it. Everyone is different.”
Spella clapped her hands again. The letters “k” and “s” vanished in a puff, and the letters “a,” “e,” “i,” “o,” “u,” and “y” appeared. These letters made two rows. “A,” “o,” and “u” were in one, and the letters “e,” “i” and “y” were the another. 
The fairy pointed at the two rows of letters and said, “Believe it or not, it is really these letters that determine in words that begin with a ‘c,’ if that ‘c’ sounds like a ‘k,’ or an ‘s’.”
Mary did not believe Spella. She wondered how vowels had anything to do with how the letter “c” sounded. However, instead of asking, Mary waited for Spella to go on.
“You see,” said Spella, as the letters “a,” “c,” “o,” and “u” began to glow. “The letter ‘c’ has the hard sound ‘k’ before ‘a’, ‘o’ and ‘u’ as in the words cat, cot, and cut.”
The letters ‘a’, ‘o’, and ‘u’ stopped glowing. Spella pointed to the other row of letters, and that started glowing.
Spella then said, “The letter ‘c’ has the soft sound ‘s’ before ‘e’, ‘i’, and ‘y’ as in the words cent, city, and cyst.”
Spella clapped her hands and the letters vanished in a puff. The fairy looked at Mary with a large smile on its face. 
Mary scratched her head. “That is kind of confusing.”
“Yes it is sort of confusing,” Spella agreed. “But English is a hard language with over one-hundred different spelling and grammar rules. For example, the ‘k’ sound can also be spelled with a ‘c’, ‘k’, ‘ck,’ ‘ch,’ or ‘que.’”
“I’m so stupid!” Mary groaned. “I’m never going to be good at spelling.”
Spella hovered in front of Mary. “Being good or bad at spelling has nothing to with being smart or dumb. Now will you let me help you learn to use the letter ‘C’?”
Mary nodded her head. Through out the night Spella helped Mary understand the rule about using the letter ‘C’ in the begging of a word. It was not long before the Mary was able to spell words with the letter ‘C’.
Spella asked, “ How do you spell the word ‘cart’?
Mary spelled. “ C-a-r-t”
“That’s right!” Spella cheered. “Now how do you spell the word ‘city’?
“C-i-t-y” Mary spelled.
Spella gave Mary a thumbs-up. “There see you got it.”
Mary gave Spella a hug. “Thank you so much for all of your help, Spella.”
“Thanks are not needed,” Spella said. “I’m a fairy after all, and fairies help people.”  
Spella signed sadly. “Now I’m sorry to say that I have to go.”
“I’m not sure how I’m going to get through school without you. No one has ever tried to help me like you did,” Mary said with tears forming in her eyes. “I wish you could stay and be my friend forever.”
“Don’t worry,” Spella said. 
Spella clapped her hands again and a card appeared in Mary’s hands.
“We will always be friends.” Spella flew in front of Mary’s nose. “If you ever need any help in spelling or grammar, just do what the card says, and I’ll come.”
Spella vanished in a puff of smoke and letters. Mary put the card on a table next her bed, lay back down on her bed, and fell a sleep.
The next day, Mary woke up thinking the whole thing had been a dream. Then she saw Spella’s card on the table and knew it had happened. She also knew it would not be the last time she would meet her fairy friend Spella, the spelling and grammar fairy.

campaign.story:
Keep up with all things XYXX related here!
Official Trailer
What is XYXX?
Imagine a near future where most individuals believe they'll find their soulmate on a dating app. It may already exist! Now imagine that same near future demands you have the trendiest dating app which requires you to upload your... DNA? A bit intrusive, right? What are the ethical guidelines when it comes to advancement in technology? Where do we draw the line between right vs. wrong? Who’s to say we haven’t crossed it? 
XYXX explores a near future in which one technological innovation alters the lives of lonely singles everywhere. Technology. Reality. Privacy. Identity. Love. These five themes are the backbone of XYXX -- and our team can't wait to tell more of these stories!
Elle (Meredith Shank) downloading XYXX for the first time
The Origins
Back in the fall of 2015, Conor Patrick Hogan and Cory McConnell came up with the idea for XYXX over a case of PBR in a Silver Lake backyard. Conor provided the PBR, Cory provided the Silver Lake backyard. Below you'll find a segment of the original pitch that was drafted from this brainstorming. It's remarkable how little was altered from its core inception. 
A segment of Conor and Cory's first story area, 10/12/15
Once the pilot was written, Conor and Cory invited four other writers (Andy Holt, Samantha Levy, Lyz May and Kim Ndombe) into the world of XYXX and fleshed out an entire first season  together. Producers Scott Sullivan, Maija Gustin and Daniel Marks provided instrumental feedback during this period too. Black Mirror was an obvious inspiration in early meetups, with Orphan Black's tonal fluidity and High Maintenance's structural ingenuity providing further assistance with our own series' blueprint. Once the entire first season was written, Conor and Cory reached out to directors and casting directors -- purposefully searching for new, unknown (to them!) accomplices who would challenge their storytelling process and collaborate on ways to make the world of the series even more grand. 
XYXX Casting Session, Spring 2016 [From L to R: Chris Redondo (Casting Director), Morgan Dameron (Director), Cory McConnell (Editor) and Conor Patrick Hogan's fingers (Writer)]
Once Morgan Dameron (director) and Chris Redondo (casting director) were aboard, the next few months blurred. Casting bled into VFX trials which bled into production meetings and, finally, 3 days of filming. From the first setup, everyone was aware that our premiere episode's leads -- Meredith Shank and Jim Cummings -- possessed an uncanny chemistry. 
Elle (Meredith Shank) first meets Harry (Jim Cummings)
XYXX was finally a living, breathing thing.
Then 2 years flew by. Sadly, no one seemed interested in XYXX. So we're moving ahead solo!
The Near Future
XYXX is a near future anthology series that aims to be pro-reality, not anti-technology. By using a black and white tableau for ‘reality’ and bright, bold colors for ‘technology’, we plan to ask our audience: just what is truly revered in society now that our screens have become so ubiquitous – is it true human connection or merely the appearance of said connection? 
Harry (Jim Cummings) previews the XYXX profile of Elle (Meredith Shank)
While this aim may appear grandiose, it’s the subtleties of the separate romances our team plan to delve into that will make this series stand out from any counterparts. Episode 1, a true world-building introduction, delves into what transpires when you begin online dating (for the first time ever!) in our near future world. Episode 2 explores the repercussions when one spouse in a relationship won’t upload their DNA to the questionably invasive app. Finally, Episode 3 tackles a high school senior's blossoming sexuality when it doesn’t necessarily match that of heteronormativity in this brave, new world.
As long as XYXX engages an audience enough to make them simply consider the moral quandaries almost on our doorstep -- while also (hopefully!) making them laugh -- the cast and crew will have accomplished their goal. 
Elle (Meredith Shank) receives a rather unwelcome text
The Plan & Crew
With your crowdfunding contribution, the team behind XYXX will shoot Episodes 2 and 3 in the Winter of 2018 and then release all three episodes as Season 1 in the first half of 2019. We're excited to have some new teammates -- Brandon Smithson (director, ep 103) and Leslie Wasserman (casting director) -- with many of our first episode's crew returning too.
CONOR PATRICK HOGAN (Co-creator / Writer / EP )
Conor Patrick Hogan stayed in the closet way past his expiration date. During his early twenties (while still closeted!) he produced a feature film, Trailerpark, based on the collection of short stories by award-winning author Russell Banks. Once he departed from Ohio (and finally came out!), he moved to LA and worked on various TV shows including Modern Family, Covert Affairs, Banshee, SIX and Chicago Med, where he is currently the script coordinator. Conor's super worried about people casually uploading their DNA to random apps, but that's why he appreciates Cory's perspective on the whole sitch.
CORY McCONNELL (Co-creator / Editor / EP)
Cory McConnell is a producer and editor living in Los Angeles. XYXX has been a labor of love during time off from his day jobs, including stints at CollegeHumor and The Ringer. He is ambivalent about uploading his DNA to phone apps, but vehemently against the proliferation of electric scooter startups.
MORGAN DAMERON (Director 101 & 102 / EP)
Morgan Dameron is an award-winning writer, director and producer who has always blazed her own path. Born in Kansas City, MO, Dameron was awarded the Women in Film and Television in Kansas City’s “Trailblazer Award” for Up and Coming Women in Film while still in high school. She received a full scholarship to the University of Southern California’s School of Cinematic Arts, where she graduated summa cum laude. She has been supported by prestigious programs such as the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, The Caucus for Producers, and Ryan Murphy’s HALF Initiative. Dameron has directed groundbreaking digital series and branded content garnering tens of millions of views. Her first feature film, Different Flowers, received rave reviews during its national theatrical release and can currently be seen on Showtime. Kansas City Women in Film and Television recently bestowed her with the “Spirit of Kansas City” award for her work bringing film production to her hometown and Duke University’s Talent Identification Program recently honored her with the Early Achievement Award. She lives in Los Angeles.
BRANDON SMITHSON (Director 103)
Brandon Smithson is a LA-based filmmaker who got his start in entertainment by shooting music videos and fashion shorts in NYC. Some of his previous work includes two music videos for Bob the Drag Queen and a behind-the-scenes short with recording artist Brandy.  In 2016, his digital series Inner Circle garnered international press and was featured in Gay Times. More recently, Brandon serves as creator of the episodic series Fish Tank which takes you on a comedic adventure into the dating lives of two trans women.
LESLIE WASSERMAN (Casting Director)
Leslie Wasserman is a casting professional for film and TV. She was recently the Casting Director for Dekkoo Series I’m Fine and Del Close documentary For Madmen Only. Her work includes Cameron Crowe’s Roadies, Strangers 2: Prey at Night and Of Kings and Prophets. Upcoming films include Lady and the Tramp, Mustang, The Devil Has a Name, City of Lies, Four Kids and It, and TV series Shark Lords. Wasserman is also a proud member of The Casting Society of America and has worked with the feature film program at Sundance Labs.
More crew announcements to follow during our campaign...!
Elle's ex Dan (Sachin Bhatt) and Elle (Meredith Shank) on a near future photo frame projector
• Have any further questions? Please feel free to reach out to us at info@xyxxseries.com! We're always happy to share more of our story with our crowdfunding supporters 💙  
• Follow along on our journey with @xyxxseries on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and thanks for being a part of the near future with us! We can't wait to share Season 1 of XYXX!

campaign.story:
The Rangers: Rise of War is a game meant to be played as an epic saga. "We are storytellers and wanted to make a game that would create lasting stories and memories with friends. Where the story about the time that the wood elf cavalry saved the day, or how the onslaught of the orc hordes could not be stopped. We wanted to create a history with our friends."
  – Ron Newcomb
The Rangers: Rise of War game has been years in the making. This game’s journey began back in 2014 as The Rangers film was being developed. Since 2015 it has been play tested by the creators and gamers to develop and refine the most diverse game play we could provide, a game that we would want to play. Each army offers a diverse makeup and features that add depth and create unique outcomes in game play. The game is set in the high-fantasy world of The Rangers, Adrasil. The Rangers franchise includes several films, as seen on The Fantasy Network, a comic book, and a live-action role playing event, "Weekend Warrior”.  
FACTIONS
HUMANS
Based in the Kingdom of Olaran, the humans are a young race, divided into the Landwards, who hold power and the Rangers, who are an elite group of warriors that are the eyes and blade of the king. The Human faction is allied to the Wood Elves. Veteran Human units can be upgraded to a Ranger. Human Heroes may inspire the populace of a region to double their production output.
WOOD ELVES
The Elven Lords like to stay to themselves, but during this time of war, the ancients must join the age of man and emerge from the depths of their hidden palaces in the Green Wood or fall under the weight of the Shadow Elves and their Orc hordes to the north. Their alliance with the Humans is tenuous and fraught with suspicion. Wood Elf units possess “swiftness” and may move 2 spaces during their turn. Wood Elf Heroes have a +1 movement and may engage enemy troops at long range with their bow in an adjacent territory during their turn.
SHADOW ELVES
The Elven Lords of the North, known as the Umbran, are an ancient and noble people. Adept in the arts of war and magic, they are fierce in battle though small in number. Their subjugated allies, the Orc hordes, make up for their lack of numbers. Shadow Elf s possess “stealth” and may move 2 spaces during their turn and a +1 initiative to the opening die roll at the start of the game. Umbran can hold +1 additional spell card. Umbran Heroes may strike and retreat in the same turn too on a die roll of 1, 2 or 3. They may also choose to attack with an Orc Horde they are adjacent to.
ORCS
The Orc Warlords and their hordes are brutal and vicious in battle. Hordes overrun and crush their enemies by tenacity and sheer weight of their numbers. The Orcs are allied to their masters, the Shadow Elves. Orc warriors cost half as much as all other units. Orcs may choose to pillage a building for half its resources in return. Individual Orc troops may also “berserk”, sacrificing themselves and tripling their attack value for one turn of combat + max unit/region ratio.
CREATURES
Should you choose to quest with your Hero, you may find yourself face-to-face with a beast from ancient days. These ancient creatures are difficult to kill and dangerous in a fight.
SHIPPING
We will be handling shipping cost after the campaign. Our goal is for Friendly Shipping worldwide with fulfillment centers and local publishers. Each of these countries (US, Canada, Europe, Australia/NZ, Asia) we plan to send bulk shipments to fulfillment partners paying VAT and fulfilling more directly. This, of course, is dependent on our order size.
Approximate shipping cost – USA: $20-$30 to most states. $30-35 to Alaska, Hawaii & Puerto Rico. CANADA: $20-$30 to most cities.LATIN AMERICA: $50-$60 to most countries. ASIA: $27 to China and Hong Kong. $40 to most other countries. OCEANIA: $18-$30 to Australia. $40 to New Zealand. AFRICA: $80 to most countries. EUROPE: $20-30 to France. $25-$35 to most other countries.
LANGUAGES
We are working with local publishers in order to respond to our international fans with translations. 
EXPANSIONS
The game brought to life via this campaign will be bundled together with any Stretch Goals unlocked, included for each backer. However, future retail iterations may offer expansion packs of items not included in the base game. 
We encourage you to get this now vs. waiting to get it retail where Stretch Goals are likely to turn into an expansion pack. 
CREDITS
The Forge Studios - Game Design, Story IP 
Jerry Mosemak - Game Art, Concept Art, Game Design
Daniel Jack Rebeiz - Video, Animation, Graphic Arts 
Steve Hamilton - Box Cover Art 
Hokunin - Concept Art 
Sam King - 3D Modeler 
Nathaniel Williams - Voice Over Artist
Justin Moe - Other Videos
FRIENDS OF THE RANGERS

Risks and challenges
Our key team members are an experienced group and have successfully completed and released projects via Kickstarter.

High Quality - We have worked hard to make sure that you receive a high-quality game. 

The Game - Gameplay has been tested and the design work was carefully thought through, but we know that the game will evolve as it grows. As with many other successful games, there will be revisions as we process your feedback. Our goal is to be responsive and make the game epic and playable.

Fulfillment - Depending on the success of the campaign, our desire would be to outsource this if our order number is high enough and makes sense.

If for some reason things go awry, we promise to frequently post updates and keep you in the loop.

DELIVERY DATE

The estimated delivery date for The Rangers: Rise of War is August 2019, but please keep in mind that this is only an estimate. Also note that due to logistical restrictions in different regions, some backers may receive their pledge rewards before others. We will be doing our utmost to avoid these situations and.

REFUND POLICY

All pledges can be refunded up to 14 days after the end of the Kickstarter campaign, fees included. Refunds may include a fee which represents approximately 15% of the full payment. Once we have started to process and packed your order, when the first ship leaves China, refunds will no longer be available. This project is being funded in USD and any refunds processed will be in the USD for the exact amount received in USD, excluding any applicable fees depending on the time of the refund being processed.

TERMS & CONDITIONS

By pledging to this project, you acknowledge that the final look, materials, and content of the rewards (and the project) are subject to change and may differ substantially from what is presented in this Kickstarter project.

If you do not log in and confirm your pledge within 8-weeks of our notification via email to confirm your pledge, you agree that we have fulfilled our obligations to you in full for payment or donations received. However, we may, at our discretion, refund or ship your pledge if you contact us and confirm your pledge after the 8 week window has elapsed.

If you confirm your pledge within 8 weeks of our notification via email, you agree that our responsibility to you is to ship your order as entered into our pledge manager system, that title and risk passes to you upon delivery to a common carrier for such shipment, and you are responsible for import duties or any other duties that may be payable to the relevant tax authorities, providing correct address information and ensuring this address is deliverable by normal methods. We regret we are unable to ship to PO Boxes.

We will do everything we can to minimize the shipping cost, but shipping shall be handle post campaign to give us the proper time to negotiate the best deals for all.

If these terms are not acceptable to you, then we suggest that you do not participate in this crowdfunding campaign and acquire the game when it is released in stores. Thank you for your understanding.

campaign.story:
Set aside the dice bags and wizard hats, my dorks—we're going to SPACE! A new novel from Matt Vancil, author of Hopjockey and creator of The Gamers and JourneyQuest.  
In a distinctly Trekkian universe, mankind has finally reached the stars! But we never shed capitalism along the way, and that lerd’s only gotten worse. 
This future is no utopia. Forget diplomacy—humanity’s presence in space is focused solely on seizing exoplants and extracting their resources. The ships of the Coalition are interstellar company towns, run by indifferent AIs and designed to keep their crews in constant debt. Inequality is rampant—if you’re wearing a red crew shirt, life sucks: you’re overworked in hazardous conditions while under constant surveillance and living on top of one another. And you have to pay for your own health care. And the whole time, the smirking officers are telling you the only reason you’re not enjoying the good life is because you’ve chosen to stay poor. So, nothing at all like the world today.
After surviving fifteen years in a red shirt, Webb is nearly burned out. She joined up like any starry-eyed kid did: to get her own ship. But that’s never going to happen—not now that the officers loathe her for being the crew’s elected (and powerless) representative, even as she’s trying to break out of the enlisted ranks herself. But rank has little to do with leadership, and hers will be put to the test when the starship Independence collides saucer-first with with a threat they’re completely unprepared for: aliens that don’t look like us.* When the ship’s social order breaks down from a truly alien threat, it’s falls to Webb to save the crew, the ship—and herself.
*You can have sex with most aliens. A lot of recruits (and backers) sign up for that.

Matt Vancil, a writer, filmmaker, and narrative designer from Tacoma. I wrote and directed the Gamers movies and created the web series JourneyQuest with Zombie Orpheus Entertainment and Dead Gentlemen Productions. I wrote video games for mobile giant King, and my work has been featured on Netflix, Hulu, and Amazon Prime. I’ve written three other books and I currently teach filmmaking at DigiPen, aka “Nintendo University.” I may have totally lifted this from my bio. 
The novel isn’t written yet, and I’d like to change that. The rest of it is mapped out and ready to go—I just need the funds to finish and publish it.
This is where I could use your help. I’m sure you’re familiar with crowdfunding by now, so I’ll just stick to the highlights. 
You can pledge for a copy of the novel as a print, electronic, or audio book. Or all three. 
You can also—and this is pretty cool—have a canon effect on the narrative. Every backer will have the name they give me listed by rank in the crew manifest at the back of the book. Those of you receiving death certificates get to specify how you died in the line of duty. And some of you will get to name red shirts and officers who will die horribly (or have their horrible deaths referenced) in the novel. 
Uh… spoilers, I guess.
 The artwork we commissioned for the pins is in! These could be yours!
Red Shirt motto: "Another Shall Rise"
Officer motto: "To the Stars, Our Birthright"
$15,000 – Brian S. Lewis records audio book
If we hit this goal, everyone's favorite undead clerical power gamer will record the audio book for The Fatal Frontier. Don't we all need more Mr. Lewis in our ears?
If the campaign is successful, our target month for delivery will be December 2019. If you’ve backed one of my campaigns before, you may have noticed a little… unintentional flexibility with the delivery dates. That’s why this one’s projected so far out.
Shipping will be handled after the campaign through BackerKit, where you can pick up additional copies and other works. Estimated shipping costs are: 
$3.99 – United States
$6.99 – Canada
$12.99 – Everywhere else

updates.update_content:
We have proof(s)!
Behold! The proofs for The Fatal Frontier have successfully rematerialized after their journey through space. The editing team and I are giving them a final once over for glitches before we put the order in. Don't worry, yours won't have that obtrusive stripe across the middle. Unless you want one, in which case... email me, I guess? Actually, no, don't do that.

Everyone out of cryostasis? Okay, good. Got a big update for you tod— oh, some of you are still a bit frosted. Eesh. You should go get a coffee or a blanket or something. I'll wait.
Okay! Nice and toasty? No? Well, keep sipping. Maybe do some jumping jacks. Here we go!
Editing is complete

Well, it's taken longer than I'd hoped, and longer than I think anyone expected, but I have finally completed a working draft of the manuscript. We have reached the summit, and all that's left is to tumble bone-crunchingly down the rocky slopes.
There's still work ahead, of course. I'll be bouncing off of rewrites and careening through the valley of editing as we pick up momentum ahead of the cliffs of fulfillment. Not really sure where this mountainfail imagery came from, but I'm sticking with it.

Greetings, loyal crew! 
It's been a while since I've tossed an update your way, so here's what's been happening with the goings of the on.
The long and short of it: progress continues, albeit at a less than optimal pace. While we are blessedly free from the health crisis that ground the project to a halt last year, it's had some lingering effects. Namely, when I put this campaign together, I budgeted out a solid block of time where I could work exclusively on the novel. Unfortunately, that time got reallocated to the aforementioned health crisis last. So instead of having one big stretch of time where this would have been the only project I was working on, I've had to attack it it in bits and pieces as I'm able to free up time from other obligations. The end result: progress has been slower than anticipated.

Hi! Hello! Just ducking my head out of the cockpit to give you a quick status update.
That status is: good. Five chapters have been written, which represent about a third to a quarter of the total book depending on how messy the climax gets. I could have phrased that better. Momentum is steady, and we remain on course to meet our predicted launch date of December, 2019.

Just a quick update today to let you know where the project stands. The writing is well underway. In fact, on that front we are slightly ahead of schedule. On the subject of fulfillment, BackerKit surveys will be sent out once the initial draft is complete, as that’s when we’ll have a more concrete sense of when the project will be done.
If you were one of our higher-level backers, please keep an eye out for some incoming emails. If you have a doomed red shirt to name or a senior officer to design, I’ll be contacting you privately. Ditto for the folks on the Captain’s Council.

campaign.story:
Introducing the third season of the acclaimed fantasy comedy One Hit Die!
PLAY

Bigger in every way—thanks to partial production funding from Telus—this web television series levels up as our roleplaying heroes explore The Devouring Dungeon in search of the mythical fountain of experience.
This Fantasy Network series is brought to you by… YOU, the fans and funders who make independent content possible! 
We are the producers of films and shows like The Gamers: Dorkness Rising, Mythica, The Rangers, JourneyQuest, The Outpost, and more. Now we’ve joined forces to create and support fan-funded, independent fantasy from around the world. 
One Hit Die Season 3 is The Fantasy Network’s first funding collaboration. An award-winning gaming comedy series from Canada, the show speaks to what we love about fantasy: huge imagination, compelling characters, and a drive to push the limits of independent production.  
One Hit Die is a fantasy comedy genre mashup of “Lord of the Rings” and “The Office”. It’s irreverent, self-aware, and hilarious.
Watch Season One for free on The Fantasy Network
In season one, the heroes begin their quest to obtain the Orb of Maldova.
Cassandra, the Paladin, believes she is the Chosen One and with the Orb she can prevent the impending doom threatening their realm.
Unfortunately for Cassandra the party she put together isn’t exactly top notch. The Wizard is constantly drunk, the Fighter kills everything (and we mean everything), and the Rogue is more obsessed with his experience points than actually finding the orb. 
Watch Season Two for free on The Fantasy Network

Still looking for the orb in Season 2, the party stumbles upon a Druid whose entire order has been murdered by the evil wizard Nerrena and her minions. Nerrena, who also wishes to obtain the orb as it belongs to the Lich Lord she brought into the realm, hunts the party down. 
Now, the adventurers think they’re ready to face the Devouring Dungeon...to find the mythical Fountain of Experience.
They’re not ready.
They’ll probably die horribly. 
PLAY

PLAY

PLAY

 Torvold Therapy Session, Season 3!
PLAY

PLAY

 Sasha Therapy Session, Season 3!
PLAY

Season 3 completed principal photography in April of 2018. Now, we need to cover post-production expenses to get this epic adventure delivered. Your pledges will help pay the editor, composer, colorist, and sound designers—basically, the people who take raw footage and make it look and sound gorgeous. 
Your support not only helps One Hit Die complete post production, but shows that an active and empowered fan base is eager to keep the story alive. With your help, we’ll premiere One Hit Die Season Three at Gen Con Indy in August, stream straight to your eyeballs (via Telus in Canada and The Fantasy Network everywhere else), and help introduce new viewers to an awesome gaming comedy! 
While this is our first campaign as The Fantasy Network, as Arrowstorm Entertainment, Zombie Orpheus Entertainment, and The Forge Studios we’ve fulfilled dozens of Kickstarter campaigns…and we know how important incredible, unique rewards are! 
What’s new and awesome about this campaign is that it includes more than One Hit Die. If you back at $25 or higher, you’ll receive a subscription to The Fantasy Network, which will let you stream ALL our shows on your desktop or via our iOS, Android, Amazon Fire, and Roku apps.
Catch up on The Gamers. Binge all five Mythica films or the complete Standard Action series. Enter the world of The Rangers and Strowlers. Be the first to stream our new releases, plus get access to our incredible fan community forums, Discord server, wiki, and more! 
New to One Hit Die? Want to complete your collection? We’ll offer DVDs and BLURAYS of Seasons 1 & 2 in BackerKit when the campaign ends. You’ll be able to add and pay for them during the survey, so don’t worry about adding funds now. 
We will charge for all shipping after the campaign in BackerKit. In order for your rewards to ship, you will need to pay shipping fees at that time.
Do NOT add shipping fees to your pledge now.
International Backers: expect to pay less than $9.00 USD in BackerKit for shipping on the basic $50 reward.
Domestic Backers: expect to pay less than $5.00 USD in BackerKit for shipping on the basic $50 reward.
We will fulfill this campaign via our partners at Ship Naked.  
In order to keep Kickstarter funds focused on supporting the production of One Hit Die, any funds added in excess of your pledge during this campaign will be treated as a contribution to improve the quality of the show and will not count as BackerKit credit. Funds received during this campaign cannot be applied to shipping or add-ons. 
Example: if someone pledges $70 for the $50 level, the extra $20 will go straight into improving the show. That backer would not receive $20 of credit to spend in BackerKit. 
Thank you for supporting One Hit Die Season 3 The Devouring Dungeon! We're excited to share this new season with you!  
Beyond pledging (and even a single dollar helps!) you can help spread the word in the following ways: 
Share this campaign and the video on social media. 
Include a statement about why you love One Hit Die. 
Share the first two seasons. 
Encourage people to appreciate what we've already made possible and help them turn into fans. 
Create and share your own fan art. We love seeing the amazing things people have made based on One Hit Die!
Write your personal One Hit Die Adventure. Write a longer piece, or shoot a video, or tweet a haiku, about what One Hit Die means to you. Make it compelling, interesting, and fun. Interact with the community. 
Post and respond to comments here, or on Facebook, or on YouTube. Get to know other fans. 
Help show the world that we're not just a group of fan funders, but friends and collaborators in building a positive, inclusive, and welcoming community. 
 Thanks for your support!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is a low-risk campaign. The hardest part, actual production, is already complete. Barring a catastrophic data loss, the only major risk is that creative works can sometimes face delays in order to make the final product perfect.

Our team has fulfilled dozens of crowdfunding campaigns (via ZOE, Arrowstorm, and The Forge), has strong existing relationships with trusted vendors, artists, and manufacturers to source our rewards, and knows how to see a campaign from inception to final delivery.

While risks come with any crowdfunding initiative, we’re confident that our track record speaks for itself.

campaign.story:
PLAY

Hey, there is a video of a full game near the bottom of the page, so if that is what you are looking for, head there first.
We did it!
And if Kickstarter had a "Funded in only 695 hours!" badge I'd be using it! Thanks to the 453 game and non-game backers who have dragged this kicking and screaming over the funding threshold. If you are coming here from the banner blitz over at BoardGameGeek, welcome! Get a game, help a gamer. Each pledge from here on out gets us towards stretch goals.
PDF rules link
We have had a few requests for the rules, so here they are. A lot of the art in these rules is placeholders and we're still tinkering with fonts and backdrops for legibility purposes, but the content is the current iteration of the rules.
July 5 - The first review is in! In German. However, you can read the somewhat amusing Google translation of it here.
Killing Lee Garvin? Huh?
Killing Lee Garvin (KLG for short) is a game with a mission. To make fun of the improbable yet inevitable mortality of game designer Lee Garvin (Tales from the Floating Vagabond, Badass Zombie Killers, etc.), which hopefully is quite a few years off. And also because on his way there he has racked up a lot of medical bills that he feels honor-bound to pay while simultaneously faced with the problem of doing so on what you can make as an indie game designer. And the minor distraction of being evicted and living in his car for the past several months. So, with the assistance of cartoonist Ron Leishman (co-creator of Captain Canuck), I'm trying to help Lee out a bit.
Greg: Being a board/card/rpg game designer is creatively wonderful, but sucks in a lot of other respects. Publishing is already a low-income zone with no job security and negligible benefits, and game design is a ghetto within that zone.
And if you are an independent game designer, it can be even tougher. Lee Garvin is a friend and like me, an indie, but unlike me, life has not been kind to him. In the sense that "being in an accident, going into a coma and waking up medically bankrupt" is "not been kind".
Among other things. Lee has endured a laundry list of improbable bad luck events that would make a good script for a slapstick version of Final Destination.
Because I'm a game designer, I see everything as having game potential, so I humorously told Lee I should make a game about killing him off. And the more I thought about it, the more it actually started to make sense...
And so, Killing Lee Garvin was born... At the time I started work on this, Lee still had a roof over his head and the project was meant to just help with his medical bills, but as his life circumstances took a more...outdoors turn, the focus has turned to helping him first get that roof (any roof) back, so that he can try to do all the things those of us with roofs take for granted.
Lee: I wasn't entirely sure Greg was serious about doing this at first, but I should have guessed; he made a game about stalking slasher victims (which I have played quite a bit). And for the record, It wasn't an accident that put me into the coma; it was the doctors who were trying to get me to breathe after I got pneumonia. The accident was a different time.
But to give an example of where the cards are coming from, long ago, in an age known as "The '80s", I was a Boy Scout (Go Troop 35!). While at one of our troop cookouts, the guys were spread out all over the grounds of the church that served as the host for most of our events. Being Scouts, we were naturally very curious about nature. Being Boys, we were reckless and quite foolish in our endeavors. Being the '80s, safety had not yet been invented. Some of my fellow scouts were expressing their curiosity towards nature by whacking a wasps' nest in a tree with a long stick. I was walking from around the other side of the building at the time, so naturally, I turned the corner just as they knocked the nest out of the tree, and it hit the ground, and all the wasps in the world flew into my open mouth. I really, really wish I could say that was the worst pain I have ever experienced.
If one accepts the "many worlds" theory of alternate realities, I died in 437 of them. But this being the 1980s, and my father being from Texas, as long as the kid could breathe and no bones were visible, he saw no reason to get medical professionals involved.  
But I did get ice cream.
Life-threatening calamities and ice cream. The Lee Garvin story...
Goals?
Greg: KLG has a few simple goals. Be a good, hilarious game. Help out Lee. The latter part is simple. After the production costs are taken into account, Lee gets half. And this is not Hollywood accounting. Lee gets most of his projected cut as fast as I can cut the check after the Kickstarter ends. And if it is funded with time to spare, I'll write as much as I can out of my own account, just to give him a head start. And the more people we get on board, the lower the production cost is per game. So, the more people that want to kill Lee, the better off he ends up. I'm not exactly sure how the karma math works on that one, however...
Lee: One thing I want to make crystal clear is that, yes, I am in a bad way (hell, I'm sleeping in my car right now), but I am not alone, and there are others who have it worse than me. So yes, I will be using some of the money from this project to dig myself out of the hole I'm in, but a full 50% of it, I intend to donate to the Jack Vasel Memorial Fund. This is an organization that has already helped me quite a bit, so I just want to return the favor. They exist to do nothing but help Gaming Professionals who have hit hard times.
About the game
KLG is a simple 3-6 player game that hides a significant amount of strategy and backstabbing. There are two ways to win. First, you can "heal" Lee and you win. Second, you can manipulate someone else into killing Lee and if you have the best game position at that time, you win. So, you can be a good guy and save him, or a bastard who engineers and then takes advantage of his untimely demise...
It's a single-deck game, with 54 cards and a bunch of tokens in three colors for representing Lee's health. Cards are simple. They have a number, a color and a type (Harm or Help). Every round you choose from a selection of face-up cards to add to your hand, play cards secretly and reveal them. Harm cards give Health tokens to other players, Help cards put tokens back in the common pool. If you get too many tokens of a particular color, Lee becomes an ex-game designer and it will all be your fault. You are a bad person and Lee's ghost will haunt you. Even if it was another player who gave you the tokens that made you lose. It's pretty easy to end the game by bringing about Lee's untimely demise, but to win you also have to have the best board position when that happens. Not so easy. So you may have to work very hard to keep him healthy...right up to the moment where you push him in front of a bus.
But you can also make deals involving the cards. And break them. You do not know exactly what other players are holding, but you do know who has what tokens and what will trigger the end of the game. So, the deals you make and the order in which they resolve is an important part of each round. So, cards are revealed and the round leader (player 1) says “Hey player 4, I won't hit you with the Squirrels if you don't Mug me”, and player 4 says “Sure thing!” Of course, since player 1 does their action first, player 4 does not have to abide by the deal, but they will. This time. 
And whoever is the current round leader has to narrate Lee's life events using the revealed cards for that round. So player 1 looks at the cards and says: 
"Lee compensated for the stresses of GenCon with a regular cardio workout. But while jogging in the park one morning he was mugged and beaten. And then the squirrels found him...”
KLG gameplay video
PLAY

A game of KLG takes ten to thirty minutes to play, and strategy really depends on who you are playing with. People who are trying to win by healing Lee will have a different strategy than those trying to bring about his premature end, and how you play depends on how many of each type of player are in your game. But you are simultaneously playing against the table (the state of tokens and their distribution) and against the other players (what are they trying to do, and to whom?). 
Stretch Goals 
$15,000: The basic game
Not really a stretch goal. This covers the production, art, the Kickstarter cut and enough room to get Lee some money. The base funding level is not low-balling it in expectation we will blow through it. It is a realistic number so that if we reach, Lee gets some help. Given the fixed costs like art (most of the cards are custom caricatures of Lee), this is the minimum level to make the game happen.
$20,000: Custom meeple
The "first player" meeple in KLG denotes who gets first pick of cards and deal-making opportunities each round. If we get $20,000 in pledges, we will have a custom meeple made that is an embarrassing caricature of Lee Garvin. My personal preference would be him looking like an out-of-shape Bane (admit it, he's meeple-shaped), but if we reach this goal, Lee will be browbeaten into supplying some pictures and people can vote on their favorite in the comments section.
$35,000: Quality upgrade 
The base level of the project turns a profit, but is a short run game and much of the cost is the artwork and the higher cost per game for short run printing. The $35,000 level is the minimum for getting a large print run from China. The lower cost per unit means we can upgrade the quality of everything. Cards, box, tray liner, rules, the works.
It's a big jump from $15,000 to $35,000, but depending on the printer I'm pretty sure we will be able to get a useful "printed in China" price for some level of pledges north of $15k but less than $35k. We are going to provide the best quality available for whatever level of pledges we do get, but this stretch goal guarantees we can go for the best. You're spending $25 on the game, we want it to look and feel like a good value for the money (in addition to repeat play value for the money).
$50,000: Organ tokens. Instead of the normal colored bits that are the health tokens, we will spring for the cost of custom blue brain, green lung and red heart tokens to represent Lee's health.
Laser-guided Chainsaw Add-on!
One of Lee's game designs is a cheesy little non-collectable card game called Badass Zombie Killers (or BZK), where the game is about preparing for the zombie apocalypse, having the coolest and most vicious gear, and the game ends when the zombies actually show up. You can download an image of the rules cards from this link.
Now, unlike Lee who is living in his car in Colorado, the irony is that the remaining stock of BZK actually has a roof over its head in Virginia, close enough to where I am to go get them. So, if you've every wanted a copy of BZK and saw that it is out of stock on Amazon and ThinkGeek, this is your way to get one. So, with the cooperation of Reality Cheque and Skortch'd Urf, this game of prepper one-upmanship can now be yours! Just add $17 to your (US-only) pledge for KLG and we will ship them both at the same time. The $17 covers the BZK and the extra cost for shipping, since we will have to go from a First Class 12oz box to a flat rate Priority Mail box.
Hobo Capitalism Add-On!
Matt Vancil suggested something to Lee after the "hobo knife" picture was posted in Update #23, and the following is entirely Lee's doing. I claim no credit for it. There is now a "Hobo Capitalism" add-on in this campaign. For US$10, a US backer will get an official Lee Garvin Hobo Knife™ (as seen in Update #23), an autographed picture of Lee holding a knife that is probably not yours (much nicer than the picture below but no guarantee he will look any more sane), and in a hat-tip to Munchkin, a special rule for Badass Zombie Killers that can only be utilized by the rightful owner of said knife. This add-on price includes postage in the US. So, you can add this to any game pledge and it will be sent to you directly from Lee's high-tech manufacturing facility, which will probably be the front seat of his 2008 Saturn.
The official Lee Garvin Hobo Knife™ has a number of unique features*. It can be smuggled through metal detectors! Each one is hand-crafted by Lee himself and will have its own unique character. It has trace amounts of Lee's DNA in case you need to leave it at a crime scene to confuse the forensic team. And in an emergency it can be disassembled to give you several feet of duct tape.
*Due to variances in the manufacturing process, the ability of the Lee Garvin Hobo Knife™ to cut anything tougher than a McDonalds pancake is not guaranteed. This product not endorsed by the SHA (Stabby Hobo Association).
And here, for the second time anywhere! The tentative official Badass Zombie Killers Hobo Knife™ Rule 
If you have an authentic Lee Garvin Hobo Knife™ in your possession, you may do the following once per game. Discard 4 Badassery worth of Weapon cards or Modifier cards from your hand (that is, the total Badassery value or bonus of the cards must add up to at least positive 4) into the Dumpster. Whip out your Hobo Knife™ and Shank one opponent's character.  
To Shank, you must choose one of that character's special abilities, and place the blade of the Hobo Knife™ so that it covers it completely. That ability is not available for use for as long as the blade remains lodged in the character (until dislodged by a special effect). At the end of the game, the Hobo Knife™ is returned to its owner. Don't make them come over there.
Shipping
Games will be shipped in the US by First Class or Priority Mail (depending on whether they top 12 ounces with the stretch goals), and tracking numbers will be available.  
Same as USA, just a little more expensive. 
EU-bound games will ship from the EU to avoid Customs charges and will go via regular mail within the EU.  
Australia-bound games will depend on the level of funding. At the low end they will be shipped via an intermediary service, while if we get into stretch goal territory we can probably use a normal fulfillment center. 
If you are backing this project from Mars, we will arrange to have your package put on the next available manned flight (losing the entire shipment we shoehorned into the Schiaparelli lander soured us on automated interplanetary delivery options). Kickstarter does not have Mars in their system so contact us privately for shipping cost. Due to Customs restrictions, we cannot ship to the Moon or other planets at this time.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is my second Kickstarter (third if you count collaborations), and the fourth that Lee has started or been a collaborator on, so while we are not "veterans", we have some experience with the process. But this one has the potential to be significantly bigger than previous ones. The project goal is modest and will turn a profit that can go to help Lee, but if it exceeds its goals by a lot, then the scaling goes from "domestic short run printing" to "seafreight container from China", and from "local pack & ship" to "hire a fullfillment service". The numbers have been run for both cases and work out, and give sufficient wiggle room for stretch goals. However, I do want to avoid "stretch goal creep", since I've seen over-promising on other projects, and overly ambitious stretch goals also cause significant production delays.

Fortunately, I have a friend in the gaming industry (Mark Walker of Flying Pig Games (look his projects up)) who is both local and has significant experience with Chinese printers and domestic and international fulfillment operations. So in the unlikely event this explodes like kittens, I'm sure there will be headaches, but the headaches will be manageable. And if worst comes to worst, I can always blame it on Lee... (Lee: Hey!)

The timeframe from "end of Kickstarter" to "game in your hands" is going to vary based on how successful it is. The moment the minimum threshold is reached, the art will be contracted and the artist is ready to go on it. If it reaches a "China production" threshold, we have several possible suppliers and will have to choose one, and if we hit the top tier for custom game pieces, this will probably add a little to the production time as well. Of course, if we hit these thresholds with time to spare it means we can get them underway even before the campaign ends. One thing that will be a delay at the high end is that seafreight will take about a month, compared to domestic short-run printing that would take a few weeks from printing to delivery. My best guess at this point is "on time or sooner" for a barely funded campaign to "a month or two late" for one with all the stretch goals, but the benefit of the latter is a much nicer looking product (and more money going towards Lee's medical bills). The listed delivery date is an intermediate value, and if you have funded other campaigns you know how that goes.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
I've gotten the last of the bills paid, run the spreadsheet and cut a check to Lee's brother. I wish the check were bigger, but the Kickstarter was barely funded and I got Lee as much as I could right after it funded without me knowing what the actual final cost would be. Turns out I came reasonably close but there was enough left that while the final payment to Shea is not huge, it is useful.
I have the leftover KLG and Badass Zombie Killers on my company web site (), and linked on the campaign page for the Kickstarter. In keeping with the spirit of the Kickstarter, half of each sale (after shipping) will go to one of the two charities that helped Lee out.

Not much to report. It was good, albeit bittersweet to meet with a few of you at Gen Con and talk about Lee. My internet is back after a nearly month-long outage, courtesy of a somewhat more expensive and hopefully more reliable HughesNet connection. It says something for tech that I have a better internet connection from 22,000 miles away by satellite than I do from a DSL hub 4 miles away by copper wire. But the main reason this update is several days after my return is that I have been trying to collect information.

My internet is now in day 16 of its outage and it seems unlikely to be restored until I return from Gen Con. You do not realize the gradual insinuation of high-ish speed net access until it is gone. I used to be able to work from a 14.4k dialup connection. Of course, web pages were optimized for low speed connections and there was not nearly as much to surf, and I relied much more on my extensive reference library of dead-tree books rather than doing some quick google-fu to get an answer. And I would go to an actual library if needed. I still have my old Library of Congress 'go back into the stacks and rummage around pass' as a souvenir of those days. . I get .25mb on a good day and live in a cell tower blind spot, so my predicament would probably be murder-inducing to someone who relied on high speed net and good mobile phone coverage. I will probably bite the bullet and go to satellite internet when I return, leaving the old copper wires to handle voice calls only.

Shortly after the last update, which was right after I got net and phone back after a storm, internet went down again. For a group of customers, rather than just me. For the past week, my internet provider (who shall remain nameless but whose initials are CenturyLink) has been giving everyone the runaround, with "service restored by N pm today", where N manages to constantly stay ahead of the present moment by dint of resetting to a new deadline when the old one is passed.

A first pass through the pre-generated postage shows about fifteen backers whose pledge would have required Lee's personal attention but either never got it, or got it but was not packed and labeled.
I have sent each of you a message through Kickstarter regarding this.
In short, you will get your game(s), and the question is whether you just want the game or the game and a refund of the item/service you did not get. I should be able to process whichever you want within a day or so of getting your reply.

This is going to be a short one, since I am typing it in a parking spot and posting it using someone' wifi connection. Lightning took out my phone and internet and it will not be back for a week, and I cannot get enough of a cellular signal for tethering from home.
The overseas KLGs did go out after much trial and tribulation. I am not geographically close to Lee and his brother has his hands full at the moment, so Lee's Facebook page is the best spot for any information at this point. My lack of connection means you will know more than me for the next few days. Thank you for the personal messages and comments. As soon as I can get more info on any KLGs that had required Lee's attention and have a connection to post it from, I will get out another update.

Which is an understatement. I was intending to update today with the news that my Fedex authorization for international bulk shipments finally went through. Which it did. However, Lee Garvin also went to the hospital this morning with chest pains and trouble breathing. And...you can see where this is going.
I will be getting the international shipments out as soon as is practical. I will check the tracking numbers on anything that had been sent to Lee and anything that he still had I will have to contact backers individually about. And any additional money that would have gone to Lee after the final accounting will instead go to one of the charities that helped Lee when he needed it.

Not a lot of news, but here is what is going on:
• Got a few undeliverable and returned games, got in touch with recipients and sent them out again.
• If you got an email about a package but did not get it, it could be because you pledged in a tier that required Lee's special attention. The preprinted mailing (and postage) generated the email when it was created, but it then had to get shipped to Lee and he has to finish working on whatever your pledge required and then dump it in the mail. All I can say on that is to check the tracking number every few days and if Lee tells me they are in the mail, I'll post a quick update to let people know.

A whopping big care package of games and sundry is headed Lee's way. That's right, the Writer's Cramp tier has been prepped and awaits Lee's tender ministrations. Also, those of you who did the add-on for the Official™ Lee Garvin® Hobo Knife™® are in luck, because the prepaid postage labels for your order are probably in that box as well.
In other news, not all is well in shipping land. I have the first non-deliverable package sitting here on my desk. So if you are Pamela and used to live in Elroy WI, get back in touch. There are also a handful of pledgers who have yet to provide any address at all. And this is not for the "nice guy" tier, but people who pledged to get a product and never provided a shipping address. I have gone to some length to track a couple of you down and leave messages (hint: a Kickstarter pseudonym does not hide you from me if you use the same Kickstarter avatar as your Facebook page and I do a reverse image search), but if you don't want to get back in touch, you just won't get your game.

The several day internet outage over, shipping continues. To get more KLG in the hands of loyal backers, I just got back from getting a few more cases to the post office. This is almost but not quite all of the basic backer tier, plus a start on the Canadian pledges. This was more of a hassle than anticipated. A basic backer was one game and US shipping, which meant a search for a given pledge amount ($31) would net me a lot of results for quick and easy postage generation. Anything other than this had to be looked at on a case-by-case basis. Was it Canadian postage? Was it a basic order plus a few extra (or a lot extra) dollars for Lee? Was it a a ? Etc.
